result.execSummary:
The defendant Nicholas M. Dyon was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Disorderly Conduct - County/Municipality. This is not a criminal offense and results only in a money penalty for this offense.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

records.addlTxt: Defendant Nicholas M. Dyon in court with attorney James C. McLaughlin.  John Martin Yackel appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Amended to County Ordinance Disorderly Conduct Forfeiture Ordinance,  DEF pleas NC, court found guilty on Count #1, Sentence imposed, fine $267.50 due in 30 days

APPEARANCES:  Defendant Nicholas M. Dyon in court with Attorney James C. McLaughlin.  John Martin Yackel appeared for the State of Wisconsin.

Defendant advised of rights/penalties, acknowledges receipt of complaint, and waives reading of complaint.  Court enters NOT GUILTY plea on behalf of DE to Count 1.  Scheduling conference scheduled for April 28, 2015 at 02:30 pm.

No abusive Contact with  -
 Alicia R Dyon and   Absolute Sobriety   No drug use without a valid prescription.
Statutory Minimum Domestic Abuse Bail Conditions
As a condition of my release from custody in this matter, I agree that I will not engage in any threats or acts of domestic abuse against the victim "  Alicia Dyon  " or any other person.
I understand that "domestic abuse" means:
Intentional infliction of physical pain, injury or illness.
Intentional impairment of physical condition. 
First, second or third degree sexual assault.  
A physical act that may cause the other person reason to fear imminent engagement in the conduct described above, including but not limited to the intentional destruction of physical property.
